cab.content: Telegrams-"SHIPMiNDER, VIC. LONDON."Any further communication on this subjoct should bo addressed to-Tlio Soorotary,Ministry of Shipping,St, Jamos's Park,London, S.W. 1,and tho following number quoted:-1Sir,In continuation of my letter of the 18th Instant, I am directed by the Shipping Controller to report for the information of the Y/ar Cabinet as follows :-1. CONVOYS.(a) Homeward Bound Convoys. Since the last report 10 convoys, consisting of 149 ships (1,053,300 tons deadv/eight) have arrived.There were four casualties by enemy action. The Norwegian steamship "SAN ANDRES". out of a Gibraltar convoy, was torpedoed and sunk 28 miles South East of Kinsale Head on the 11th instant. The s/s "DENBIGH HALL" was torpedoed 90 miles South West of the Soillies and sunk on the 18th instant. The s/s "SCHOLAR" was torpedoed and sunk on the 15th instant 70 miles West of the Scilly Islands, and the s/s "HURUHUI" was torpedoed and sunk on the 18th instant at the entrance to the English Channel also off the Scilly Islands.The s/s "SSPERANZA DE LARRIHAGA" was also torpedoed on the 15th instant off the North of Ireland, but was sub-sequent ly brought into Lough Swilly.The Dutch steamship "ZAANLAiiD" was sunk in collision in mid ocean owing to fog.There are now on passage home 25 convoys consisting of 370 ships.(b)/IE SECRETARY, WAR CABINET.MINISTRY OF SHIPPING, (b) Outward Bound Convoys. Since the last report 13 Convoys, consisting of 167 ships (1,323,000 tons deadweight) have been escorted through the danger zone.The s/s "MOTROCINE" was torpedoed and sunk on the 17th instant at the entrance of the English Channel, and the s/s "CLAN MACKAY" collided with the s/s "EURYPYEUS" in Gibraltar Harbour, on the 14th Instant, and sank.Out of a Liverpool Convoy of the 16th instant the s/s "AENEAS" went ashore on Rathlin Island owing to fog, and the "ORIANA" and the "MANORA" on Torcer Point.The "AENEAS" has been floated and taken to Belfast, and it is hoped to salve the other two vessels.There are now In the danger zone 3 Convoys consisting of 69 ships. FINANCE,During the week ended the 18th instbant, the sum of 2,184,734 was paid in compensation for loss of requisitioned ships, mailing a total of 8,350,608 paid on this account since the 1st April, 1918. REQUISITIONED FOREIGN TONNAGE.The following foreign steamers have been requisitioned:-Russian s/s "SINEUS" "BESSARABIA" "ALBATROSS""KOuRSK" "ZIM0R0D0K". Dutch s/s "MAASHAVEN".The Russian steamship "TRIO" reported as requisitioned in my letter of the 23rd March, has been found to be unsuitable and the requisition cancelled.The Russian s/s "GENERAL SUWOROW" and "GENERAL SCHUWALOW were reported requisitioned on the 6th April in error. These steamers are running on Blue Book rates for the British Governmen LOSSES AND GAINS Off BRITISH TONNAGE.The losses of British steamers of 500 gross tons and upwards during the week ended the 18th instant were as follows:-Lost/ mf'Lost by enemy action *.. 12 ships of 47,918 gross tons " " marine peril ... J_" of 14,184 " "making a total of ... 14 ships of 62,102 gross tons.The gains were as follows:-New vessels (British built) brought into service:-8 ships of 43,292 gross tone making a net loss of 6 ships of 18,810 $ross tonsIn addition there were transferred from the foreign flag:-5 ships of 14,856 gross tons.This, while representing additional tonnage under the British flag, is not additional tonnage available for service, as the vessels now transferred have already been engaged in the service of the Allies. STANDARD SHIPS,The s/s "WAR GLEN" and "WAR FOAM" have been delivered. STORES FOR THE BRITISH ARMY IN FRANCE.In the week ending 18th May, 174,492 tons of Military Stores were discharged in France, including 41,126 tons of Ammunition.EXCHANGE OF BRITISH AND GERMAN PRISONERS OP KAR.The fifteenth exchange of British and German Prisoners of tfar has taken place. The Dutch ships on this service dis-emfearked 259 military and 14 civilian English prisoners at Boston, and took on board 29 military and 40 civilian German prisoners.I am,Sir,Your obedient Servant, (Sgd,) John Anderson.
